repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Cedric N. Chatterley photographs
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: The photographs of Cedric N. Chatterley span the years 1983-2013, and were created throughout his career as a documentary photographer, beginning with his MFA thesis project on religious experience in the U.S. The photographs are primarily black-and-white prints ranging in size from 8x10 to 18x24 inches. The most prominent themes in Chatterley's work are labor, community, and religious expression. He has photographed chicken slaughterhouse workers in Maine; Cambodian immigrants in North Carolina; David "Honeyboy" Edwards and other Southern blues musicians in Mississippi and on tour; a substance abusers' rehabilitation community in Durham, N.C.; tornado survivors in South Dakota; an abandoned religious theme park in Connecticut; and sheep rancher Judith Fae "Pachy" Burns in Montana. Some of his documentary work also includes oral history interviews. There are also several recordings of interviews with Chatterley, where he speaks about his work as a documentary photographer, and a book by Barbara Lau containing his photographs of Cambodian immigrants. Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is comprised of nine thematic series: the first is Career Retrospective, 1983-2007, with nine sub-series: Social Events, Religious Iconography, Labor, Southern Landscapes, Travel, Family, Maine Folklife, TROSA, and Downeast North Carolina. The other series are in chronological order: Holy Land, USA; MFA Thesis; Penobscot Poultry; David "Honeyboy" Edwards; Spencer, South Dakota; Triangle Residential Options for Substance Abusers (TROSA); Sheep Ranching in Montana; Other Images; and Publications and Interviews.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. However, all reproduction requires permission of the photographer who retains the copyrights.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
Original audiovisual materials are closed to patron use. Some use copies are available.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Cedric N. Chatterley Photographs were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2008, 2009, and 2014.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The photographs of Cedric N. Chatterley span the years 1983-2013, and were created throughout his career as a documentary photographer, beginning with his Master in Fine Arts thesis project, Ambivalent Ecstasies/Converging Energies, on American religious experience. The photographs are primarily black-and-white gelatin silver prints ranging in size from 8x10 to 18x24 inches.

The most prominent themes in Chatterley's work are labor, community, and religious expression. He has photographed chicken slaughterhouse workers in Maine; Cambodian immigrants in North Carolina, a project undertaken with Barbara Lau of the Center for Documentary Studies at Duke University; David "Honeyboy" Edwards and other Southern blues musicians in Mississippi and on tour; a substance abusers' rehabilitation community in Durham, N.C., also with Barbara Lau; tornado survivors in South Dakota who rebuilt their town over a period of ten years; Holy Land USA, an abandoned religious theme park in Connecticut; and a woman sheep rancher's work during lambing season in Montana. Some of the images were taken with Chatterley's hand-built cameras.

A final series consists of materials relating to Barbara Lau's book, From Cambodia to Greensboro, documenting Cambodian immigrants in North Carolina, that includes images taken by Chatterley, and a set of recorded interviews from 2008 in which Chatterley speaks about his career as a documentary photographer. The cassettes have been converted to digital files and use copies are available for access. Original recordings are closed to use.
Series are arranged in chronological order; prints are numbered and captioned by the photographer.
Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

did.unittitle: Career Retrospective Series, 1983-2007

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of nine sub-series spanning Chatterley's career as a documentary photographer: Social Events, Religious Iconography, Labor, Southern Landscapes, Travel, Family, Maine Folklife, TROSA, and Downeast North Carolina, with the bulk of the series made up of Social Events and Labor. Original captions were taken from back of prints. Subseries are arranged in a chronological sequence; the 127 prints within are in original order as received.

Holy Land USA Series, 1985-1986 and undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of 50 8x10 inch selenium-toned gelatin silver prints and one larger undated laminated color placemat. Built in 1958, Holy Land USA was a religious roadside attraction in Waterbury, Connecticut. The images document the condition of the park, which closed in 1984 after 26 years of operation. Original captions taken from back of prints. Many of the images were printed in 2001. Prints are in original order as received.

MFA Thesis Series, 1987

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of three 11x14 inch and 40 18x24 inch gelatin silver prints for Chatterley's Master of Fine Arts thesis at Southern Illinois University at Carbondale, entitled Ambivalent Ecstasies/Converging Energies. This body of work explores religious ecstatic experience. The three 11x14 prints offer a panoramic shot of the thesis exhibit, while the forty 18x24 prints form the body of work for the thesis project. The prints have no captions but are numbered sequentially, with information included that indicates their positions in the exhibit, and the date of the exhibit, May 6, 1987.

Penobscot Poultry Series, 1988-1994

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of 91 11x14 inch and 10 16x20 inch gelatin silver prints. On February 24, 1988, Penobscot Poultry in Belfast, Maine closed down. Chatterley documented the final days of the last chicken processing plant in the state and followed former employee Linda Lord as she sought new employment afterwards. The plant became the subject of the book, I Was Content and Not Content: The Story of Linda Lord and the Closing of Penobscot Poultry by Alicia J. Rouverol and Stephen A. Cole, with Chatterley contributing the photographs. Original captions, with Chatterley's contextual side comments, were taken from back of prints. Arranged chronologically.

David "Honeyboy" Edwards Series, 1990-1996 and undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of 119 11x14 selenium-toned gelatin silver prints and contact prints documenting Mississippi Delta blues guitarist David "Honeyboy" Edwards. Images were taken between 1990 and 1996. They feature Edwards and the places he visited while touring the southern and midwestern United States, including Arkansas, Chicago, and Louisiana, and images of Honeyboy visiting friends, relatives, and locations from his boyhood towns of Shaw and Greenwood, Mississippi. Some images feature fellow blues musicians who appeared with Honeyboy in concerts and recording sessions. Original captions with Chatterley's contextual side comments were taken from back of prints. Arranged chronologically.

Spencer, South Dakota Series, 1998-2008

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This large body of work consists of images documenting the aftermath of a powerful tornado that caused the nearly total destruction of Spencer, South Dakota (McCook County) by a tornado on May 30, 1998, as well as the subsequent rebuilding of the town, and the tenth anniversary of the tornado. The photographer, Cedric Chatterly, is a resident of South Dakota. Original captions are taken from back of prints. The 268 gelatin silver prints are arranged in original order as received, with some gaps in numbering present.

did.unittitle: 11x14 gelatin silver selenium-toned prints
Jenny Phillips with her cat who was miraculously saved after the tornado, May 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is one of the very first photographs I made when I arrived a half a mile north of Spencer on May 31, 1998. People were gethering on the corner of South Dakota Highway 38 and County Road 431. A state police barricade would stop many people from entering, including residents. I entered easier than most with my Press Pass. Governor Bill Janklow was there giving the "go ahead" to anybody wanting to board the bus.

did.unittitle: Entering Spencer by way of Department of Corrections bus the day following the tornado, May 1998
Christ figure atop the remains of St. Matthews Lutheran Church in Spencer, May 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: F-4 tornado hit the town around 8:30 pm, May 30, 1998.

did.unittitle: Department of Corrections inmate gathering remains of Evelyn's Antiques the day following the tornado in Spencer, May 1998
Apartments (left) where elderly people died in the tornado & across the street from the apartments (right), Spencer, May 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This print was made from two negatives printed consecutively.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A kid on a four-wheeler wanted to show Chatterley where a circular saw blade had stuck itself into a tree. This print was made from two negatives printed consecutively.

did.unittitle: Newscaster at live broadcast in Spencer, June 1998

Kara Arends and Danny Stone looking at a few of their recovered belongings three days after the F-4 tornado. Danny's pickup is upside down on the right side of the image. Both of them were at home at the time with one month old Brandon, their son, June 1998
Jenna Webb and Cliff Carlin in the house in Spencer where Jenna's grandmother lived at the time of her passing, June 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cliff had lived in this house for six months and had considered buying it from the Webbs. The mud on the walls of the house was caused by the water tower falling to the ground during the tornado.

did.unittitle: Before the big news conference held on June 3, 1998 in Spencer

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Among those present are Governor Bill Janklow, Senator Tom Daschle, Senator Tim Johnson, FEMA Director James Lee Witt, and Vice President Al Gore.

did.unittitle: Milford Hickman, Division Commander for the Salvation Army, being congradulated by Vice President Al Gore in Spencer, July 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This print was made from two negatives printed consecutively.

did.unittitle: June 4, 1998 - the day nearly 5,000 volunteers came to Spencer to help "comb" the entire town for valuables, clothing, tools, and anything that had not already been picked up

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Governor Bill Janklow asked for 500 volunteers through media outlets just days prior to this event. A F-4 tornado came through Spencer around 8:30 on May 30, 1998, destroying nearly 75% of a town with 325 people. Only six people were killed.

Workers rebuilding the tornado-destroyed bank in Spencer, January 1999

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: It was snowing and the windchill was around 25 degrees below zero.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: I rented this studio space from August 1997 to March 2007. This print was made from two negatives printed consecutively.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Danny is the main canvas sewing employee at Spencer Canvas in Mitchell, South Dakota. He designed and made all the awning for his house.

did.unittitle: Lloyd Webb and me looking for a lost calf about three miles north of Spencer, February 1999

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This print was made from two negatives printed consecutively.

did.unittitle: Lloyd Webb putting down a cow that had major problems following the still-birth of a calf the night before, Valentine's Day, 2000

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This was the day (ironically) that we rounded up the last of the cattle on Webb's farm, putting an end to three generations of having cattle on this land. The dead calf was close by and the mother cow was nearly dead at the time of this shooting. It was 15 degrees and windy.
This print was made from three negatives printed consecutively.

did.unittitle: Mother cow after Lloyd Webb put her down (hole in skull).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Her calf is twelve feet away (left). Complications arose the night before while giving birth in the north pasture. Ironically, this was the day Lloyd and I rounded up the remaining cattle for market, leaving the Webb's land free of beef -- only about twenty horses remained. Valentine's Day, February 14, 2000. McCook County, South Dakota.

did.unittitle: Lloyd Webb (right) and a neighbor herd the very last cows to a trailer to take to market, three miles north of Spencer, Valentine's Day, 2000

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: They were among the 25 or 30 that remained on Lloyd and Nancy Webb's farm, thus ending the bovine legacy that began with her father. Nancy refused to help because she was too emotional about this event.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lloyd will buy a 1952 Chevy later in the year. He had a 1953 Chevy heavily damaged in the tornado and regrettably let Bernie Opland crush it and haul it off.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This was pertaining to his contractor abandoning the Stone's home construction in Spencer and leaving them $35,000 in debt. A court settlement was finally reached but the Stones filed for bankruptcy a few years later.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

I ran over Richard Nixon when the dog came running out to greet me at Lloyd's birthday party in late March 1999. Lloyd and I took him to the vet in Salem, got him fixed up and returned to the farm to finish the party. They made a pen in the house to keep Richard Nixon from running.

did.unittitle: Part of the urban planning meeting held for Spencer residents in the McCook County High School gymnasium, June 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The books on the left were being sold by Salvation Army Volunteers. The display board on the right listed all the families and home sites affected by the May 30th tornado. Urban planners from Sioux Falls had suggested that those who rebuild in Spencer try and do so by possibly trading their property and building closer together. Believing that not everybody in Spencer would rebuild, they wanted to avoid large gaps between homes. The idea was roundly rejected by those who planned to stay.

did.unittitle: Dave and Mary Twedt, Independence Day, 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: After having their home in Spencer destroyed by a F-4 tornado, they have decided to rebuild their commercial property into a home 1/2 mile south of town. This was once the Golden Pheasant Restaurant and Lounge. Legend has it that an artist traveling through sometime in the 1950s painted the scenic mural on the wall in exchange for several days stay in the adjoining motel. I tried to talk Dave into letting the mural remain in what would become their living room. Consideration was given but the mural fell to the Twedts' hammers the following week. Over the month of July, the Twedts and I filled several dumpster loads in the gutting process of this property.

did.unittitle: Mary and Dave Twedt, Gilbert Schuchardt and Danny Stone in front of Gilbert's home currently under construction in central Spencer, facing southwest, July 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Twedts and I used to take a daily cruise through town as a way to take a break from working on their home. Dave called these little rides into town as "dress codes" or "inspecting the dress code" out of a tongue-in-cheek poke at the recent building code enforcements that followed the tornado. Dave was very vocal about the local politics.

did.unittitle: Mary and Dave Twedt surveying the items recovered by the 5,000 volunteers who had combed Spencer, July 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 5 days after a F-4 tornado destroyed 75% of the town organized volunteers then cleaned recovered items and set them on tables in the McCook County High School gym. The clothes that had been recovered were taken to the Springfield State Prison near Yankton where they were laundered in 200 pound capacity machines. Other items were cleaned and sorted by local organizations. I saw several people, including Dave and Mary, pick up and examine items that had been theirs prior to the tornado, then return them to the table. Dave said, "Some things are better left alone..." Upon walking into the gym for the first time, Nancy Webb said, "This is worse than the tornado." Many folks stood over the tables that had been covered with photographs from a period of at least 100 years and wept openly. It was the most powerful photo exhibit I had ever witnessed.

did.unittitle: Mary Twedt holding three family photographs: Jessica (her and Dave's daughter) as a toddler in a high chair, Dave Twedt at age 4, and Mary at about 18 months, July 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mary is wrapped in a quilt made by her grandmother. The Twedts and I were in the McCook Central High School gym where all the items recovered after the tornado by volunteers had been set out. There were 7-8 tables of nothing but photographs. The quilt and these photographs were among the many items that filled the gymnasium.

did.unittitle: Mary and Dave Twedt in the McCook Cental High School gymnasium, July 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Clothing and objects that had been picked up by volunteers after the tornado were stacked on tables for Spencer residents. Over 5,000 volunteers combed Spencer on June 5, filling plastic bags with clothing, kitchen appliances, utensils, and many personal items. More than 7 tables were completely covered with carefully cleaned photographs. Mary is holding a quilt made by her grandmother.

did.unittitle: Mary Twedt holding up a can of beer to celebrate flowing water from the well, July 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Twedts had been without running water for 45 days following the tornado. The Twedts are now rebuilding commercial property into a home. The property was once the Golden Pheasant Restaurant and Lounge with several hotel rooms. Dave Twedt bought this property in 1986, several years before they bought their home in Spencer about 1/2 mile to the north. The Twedts and I filled the dumpster (right) more than 3 times with material during the "gutting" process. The Twedts lived in the camper trailer for 6 months while working on their home.

did.unittitle: Delphia Stuby with her granddaughter, Kallie Kennedy Rogers, on Delphia's lot in northwest Spencer, July 30, 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Kallie's father, Ed Rogers, dressed in white. Delphia's new home was built by South Dakota State Penitentiary inmates on site at the Springfield prison yard near Yankton. The interior is 768 sq ft, two bedrooms, one bath. Applicants must be 62 or older, or 18 with disability. The cost was $19,400, including delivery. Five of these homes were purchased in 1998/99 by families displaced by the tornado, three of which were placed in Spencer. Although Kallie and her parents moved to Michigan, Delphia said later, "Kallie is fifth generation Spencer."

did.unittitle: Lloyd Webb shoveling refuse from the newly re-built entry to the farmhouse, McCook County, three miles north of Spencer, South Dakota, the day before Thanksgiving, 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He taught me how to operate the backhoe and I got pretty good at it. However, two weeks later I accidently pulled up and severed the main power lines that had recently been buried (near the center of this image). I was digging a phone line and the hired electrician was the only other person there at the time. He said folks get killed doing that sort of thing. When Nancy came home later, I admitted my mistake. She laughed and said, "Don't worry about it! Lloyd does that sort of thing all the time." I held a flashlight late into the night while the electrician repaired it.

did.unittitle: Dave Twedt making his famous sign of protest

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: It eventually read: THE BIBLE SAYS ASK AND YOU SHALL RECEIVE SARIN SAYS BE BROKE, BE HUMILIATED, BEG, AND MAYBE WE'LL HELP WITH DONATED MONEY. SARIN (Spencer Area Recovery and Interfaith Network) was a faith-based organization headed by the Rev. Mark Dickson, pastor of the Sun Prairie Baptist Church near Salem, South Dakota. Nearly 1 million dollars was collected in donations and SARIN was responsible for distributing the funds--which they did mainly to those who were under (or not) insured. The Twedts felt this was unfair. Dave made this sign in December, 1998 and it was stolen from his property on Christmas Eve, 1998.

did.unittitle: Dave Twedt applying a band-aid to his finger, Mary Twedt watching, December, 1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: They are living in the garage area of the commercial property currently under re-construction. The "home" part of the building process will not be ready for several more weeks. They were nearly to their wit's end.

did.unittitle: Dave Twedt being interviewed by a television reporter from Sioux City, Iowa, about his sign (on the Jeep) protesting SARIN's method of spreading money donated by the public, McCook County, South Dakota, December, 1998

did.unittitle: (Left) Mary Twedt holding a photograph of the house in Spencer, South Dakota where she and her husband, Dave, lived at the time of the May 30, 1998 tornado. They were in the basement at the time. (Right) Dave Twedt holding a photograph of an 8 foot square sign he made to protest SARIN (Spencer Area Recovery and Interfaith Network), a faith based organization put in charge of allocating nearly 1 million dollars of donated money to help Spencer residents, February, 1999

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Because the Twedts were well insured, like many others, SARIN helped those who were not insured--from the very beginning. Dave felt the money should have been distributed evenly. His sign was stolen on Christmas Eve, 1998. Two negatives printed consecutively.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hillbilly golf is a game played with two golf balls attached by a string of 18 inch rope. Each player has a set of three, and they toss them one at a time to one of two "gates" set about 20 feet apart. When a flopping string of golf balls catches a rung and stays on or wraps itself around, points are awarded: 3 points for the top, 2 for the middle, 1 for the bottom. The player who gets 21 points first wins.

did.unittitle: The enigmatic Lloyd Webb (Vicki and Nancy in the background, the north pasture), McCook County, South Dakota, September 27, 2008

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: I had not seen Lloyd in nearly four years--about the time he and Nancy divorced. When this image was made, he was living in Sheldon, Iowa, an hour and a half from Sioux Falls and working in an ethanol plant. I once thought of him as my closest friend in South Dakota... Many people thought the tornado had hardly fazed Lloyd, and they were probably correct. But nobody in his family called and asked how he was in the weeks that followed the storm... This image was made the day Suzy Webb married her high school boyfriend, Mike... Lloyd had not been out to the farm in nearly three years. It was hard to know what he was thinking.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The home in the center of the photograph belongs to Cookie Mentle. Her son Troy once owned the car in the driveway. Troy, Richard Stone, and another boy were fishing during the day of the May 30, 1998 tornado. They were in Troy's garage cleaning fish when Troy saw the tornado coming into town. He managed to get himself, Richard and the other boy into a storm cellar just seconds before the tornado passed over them. Richard Stone credits Troy for saving his life. Troy died the following Halloween weekend from liver failure due to excessive drinking. He was living an apartment in Sioux Falls, South Dakota. I spoke to him on the phone just a few days before. His name is present on the tornado memorial in town along with the six others who passed on May 30, 1998. The Stones' house is in the distance to the left.

Triangle Residential Options for Substance Abusers, 2002 and undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1994, the Durham, North Carolina based Triangle Residential Options for Substance Abusers (TROSA) is a multi-year residential program that enables substance abusers to be productive, recovering individuals by providing comprehensive treatment, work-based vocational training, education, and continuing care. Chatterley's photographs document the program and its residents in the spring and summer of 2002. Consists of one 11x14 print, two 6x20 prints, and eleven 16x20 prints, all selenium-toned gelatin silver prints. Captions were created by the photographer; prints are in original order as received.

Sheep Ranching in Montana, 2004-2005, 2013

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series explores the intense work of sheep ranching during lambing season, with photographs taken by Chatterley near Greenough, Montana, United States, in the spring seasons of 2004 and 2005. The series focuses on rancher Judith Faye "Pachy" Burns, who ran the operation with the help of friends, daughters, shearers, and a migrant worker family from Per. The photographer's own niece was also helping out at the time the series was shot. Pachy Burns passed away some years later. After her death, Chatterley visited her daughters, Bluesette Campbell and Piney Hardiman, and their father, in Red Lodge and Scotch Coulee, Montana, in 2013; there he took six more photographs, and recorded oral histories concerning Pachy Burns, her family, and her life as a rancher.
All of the 97 black-and-white selenium-toned prints measure 16x20 inches. Captions were created by the photographer.

did.unittitle: My niece, Felice Austin (at left) and Pachy Burns (at right) pulling a lamb/catching a lamb. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004.
Pachy Burns (at left) and Felice Austin (at right) sorting lambs and sheep. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004.
Fran Woody holding a lamb at the docking table, Pachy Burns with knife/scraper. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring 2004. Fran was from Ohio, and was a very active participant in "Jam to Lamb."
Pachy Burns "banding" a lamb's tail so it will eventually fall off. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004 "Jam to Lamb."
Fran Woody (at left), Pachy Burns (at right) and my niece, Felice Austin (at right). Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004 "Jam to Lamb."

Fran Woody (left), Louise Swartzwalder (center) and Pachy Burns. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004 "Jam to Lamb." We were out walking, looking for anything that might harm the sheep (barbed wire pieces, etc.) and Fran is holding a sheep's tail she found--among many to be found.

Pachy Burns and Esteban Lozano, Sr. helping with a difficult birth. Esteban comes from Peru and has worked with Pachy nearly year-round. He also has his sons come up from Peru to help--Esteban, Jr., Ricky, and Rufo.
Pachy Burns reaching in for a lamb, Esteban Lozano, Sr. and Esteban, Jr. holding on. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring 2004.

Denise R. Gentsch tending to sickly lamb. She and her husband, Bryan, were "Jam to Lamb" particpants in the Spring of 2004. Greenough, Montana.

Fran Woody showing digitized images of sheep to me from her computer. Bryan Gentsch's back facing the camera. We were in the tent set up to accomodate "Jam to Lamb" participants. Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004.
Bryan Gentsch, Louise Swartzwalder (standing), Fran Woody, with computer, Felice Austin and Pachy Burns. 2004 "Jam to Lamb," Greenough, Montana.
Sheep on the run--The property at "Paws Up" Ranch--leased to Pachy Burns, Greenough, Montana--Spring 2004.
Just outside our tent--cooking lamb sausage for dinner. 2004 "Jam to Lamb" event, Greenough, Montana
Esteban Millan Lozano Jr. and Sr. feeding "bums" (lambs who were rejected by their mothers). Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004.

Pachy Burns (left) and Bryan Gentsch (far right) attend to wheel problems on Pachy's Airstream trailer. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004. Bryan is from Austin, Texas. He and Pachy met at an agricultural conference years earlier.
Linda Brunckhorst holding a lamb. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004. Linda was a long-time friend of Pachy's and would often show up to help.

Linda Brunckhorst, a friend of Pachy Burns . . . Pachy's vintage Airstream trailer and "Jam to Lamb" tent. The buildings belonged to "Paws Up" Ranch, from which Pachy had a lease. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004.

Pachy Burns and Linda Brunckhorst numbering lambs with red or blue (harmless) ink. Pachy had an elaborate system of keeping track of births and bloodlines that was unusual for raising sheep. She kept a LARGE book of hand-written records everybody called "The Bible." Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004 "Jam to Lamb." (I love the earrings!)

My niece, Felice Austin, with newly "branded" lamb--(harmless ink). Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004. (Felice is the oldest of four children of my sister, Nancy Jane Austin, who passed in 1989. Felice was 12 at the time.)

Pachy Burns (left), Denise Rhodes Gentsch (center) and Linda Brunckhorst getting ready to doctor a lamb. The little medical kit was created by Jennifer Nelson, a previous "Jam to Lamb" participant and friend of Piney Hardiman--Pachy's oldest daughter. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004.
Denise R. Gentsch (left) and Linda Brunckhorst working on a lamb's infected umbilical cord. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004 "Jam to Lamb."

Esteban Lozano, Jr. balancing on the "jugs" (a term used to describe the small, wooden pens made to holds ewes/lambs). Esteban was working for Pachy in order to save money to finish dental school in Peru.
My niece, Felice Austin, sewing Pachy Burns' torn jacket. Inside Pachy's vintage Airstream trailer. Near Greenough, Montana, Spring, 2004.

Inside Pachy Burns' vintage Airstream trailer. The small picture of a man on a horse (about center) is of her husband, Horatio "Rasch" Burns--a successful cattle rancher in Big Timber, Montana. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004.
My niece, Felice Austin, feeding a sick lamb in the middle of the night. The lamb died sometime the next morning, and Felice was devastated. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004 "Jam to Lamb."
Pachy Burns reviewing notes. Losing lambs was something Pachy took very seriously. She leased from "Paws Up" Ranch, hence the large out buildings. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004.
Judith Faye "Pachy" Burns with lamb. Greenough, Montana--2004 (May).
Pachy Burns with sickly lamb. Greenough, Montana, 2004 "Jam to Lamb" in springtime.
Pachy Burns (left) and Denise R. Gentsch (from Austin, TX) feeding "bums"--lambs rejected by their mothers. Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004 "Jam to Lamb."
Bryan and Denise Gentsch built this feeding station to accomodate "bums"--lambs rejected by their mothers. Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004 "Jam to Lamb."
Bryan and Denise Gentsch in the tent shared with "Jam to Lamb" participants. Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004.
Esteban Millan Lozano Jr. and Sr. out on the range with sheep. Photograph made with 35mm panoramic camera. Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004.
Mother ewe and lambs, just outside their "jug" or pen. Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004. The lamb at the bottom of photograph was born just that hour.
Remains of sheep who died for various reasons. About 50 yards from the camp/tent/buildings. Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004.
Esteban Millan Lozano, Sr. out walking--about 200 yards from the camp for "Jam to Lamb" participants. Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004.

I don't remember the reason why this lamb, several weeks old, was strung up. I want to say it was cooked for dinner that evening, but I can't be certain. Maybe it was butchered and given to somebody. Greenough, Montana, "Paws Up" Ranch building, Spring, 2004.

Strung up lamb. Bryan Gentsch beheaded it, and I believe he skinned it as well. "Paws Up" Ranch building (property that was leased to Pachy Burns for her "Jam to Lamb" events and for summer grazing), Greenough, Montana, Spring, 2004.

My niece, Felice Austin (left), Pachy Burns (center) and Linda J. Brunckhorst (from Big Timber, Montana) in the tent used for "Jam to Lamb" participants. Pachy had lots of reading material pertaining to sheep and also agriculture in general. She was a natural and gifted teacher. Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004.
Pachy Burns involved in a difficult birth. The lamb died during the process. Greenough, Montana, "Jam to Lamb"--Spring, 2004.

Pachy Burns preparing to remove the skin of a stillborn lamb, afterwhich she will place the skin on a live lamb in order for it to bond to the mother ewe (who produced the stillborn) with the hopes of bonding the "bum" lamb (rejected by its mother) to a new mother ewe. Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Number four in a series of six photographs.

did.unittitle: Denise R. Gentsch (left) and Pachy Burns with newly grafted lamb. They are planning to put this "bum" lamb with a mother ewe that gave a stillbirth (the stillborn lamb's skin is on the "bum" lamb). Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Number five in a series of six photographs.

did.unittitle: Bryan Gentsch and Pachy Burns dressing a "bum" lamb (rejected by its mother) with the skin of a lamb who died at birth or shortly after. The bum lamb will be put in a pen with the mother ewe who lost the stillborn, and hopefully the two will bond. Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004 "Jam to Lamb."

Mother ewe bonding with a "bum" lamb who has been dressed with the skin taken from the stillborn lamb (of this mother ewe). This method does not always work, but this time it did. The mother bonded with her "new" lamb. The skin will be removed in 3 or 4 days. Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004 "Jam to Lamb" event.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is the number six photograph in a series of six.

did.unittitle: Pachy Burns with a skin that had been on a "bum" lamb after it was successfully grafted to a new mother (who lost her own stillborn lamb from which the skin was taken). Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2004 "Jam to Lamb" event.
Herd of sheep just before being shorn. On the property of Paws Up Ranch (leased to Pachy Burns), Greenough, Montana, Spring, 2005.

Dan Ward getting ready to shear sheep. On the property of Paws Up Ranch (leased to Pachy Burns). Dan is inside the custom-built mobile unit made specifically to shear sheep. He is pulling on custom, handmade footwear he uses while shearing. Greenough, Montana, Spring, 2005.
Dan Ward in the mobile sheep-shearing unit. Greenough, Montana, Spring, 2005.
Dan Ward in the mobile sheep-shearing unit/trailer. Paws Up Ranch (leased to Pachy Burns) near Greenough, Montana, Spring, 2005.
Dan Ward shearing sheep inside the mobile sheep-shearing unit/trailer. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.

The mobile unit used to shear sheep, on the property of Paws Up Ranch, Greenough, Montana. The sheep would climb the ramp on the left, go inside and get sheared, then he let out doors on the (right) side of the trailer. Rufo Lozano is center. Spring, 2005.
Michael H. Peters stretching for a few minutes before he begins to shear sheep. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.
Will Tusick shearing sheep in a mobile unit, on the property of Paws Up Ranch, Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.

Will Tusick shearing sheep in a mobile shearing trailer, Greenough, Montana. Will was very articulate about sheep shearing, and he shared in great detail the proper ways to stand, how to shear quickly and easily. He was adamant about doing the best job without hurting the sheep in any way. Spring 2005.
Apparatus used for shearing sheep--inside the mobile sheep-shearing unit owned by Keith and Cyndee Braeten, on the property of Paws Up Ranch, Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.

Bluesette Campbell, Pachy Burns' youngest daughter, helping with newly sheared wool. She and her sister, Piney Hardiman, were visiting their mother briefly at the time. Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.

The front end of the mobile sheep-shearing unit/trailer. From left to right (standing): Cyndee Braeten, Bluesette Campbell, Esteban Millan Lozano, Sr.. Paws Up Ranch, Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.
Judith Faye "Pachy" Burns with an armload of newly sheared sheep wool. Paws Up Ranch, Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.

Sorting and sifting newly sheared wool. This rig was made from PVC tubing and served to do a quick cleaning of the wool. Pachy Burns is on the far right. Paws Up Ranch property, near Greenough, Montana. Spring, 2005.

Kess Kintla Nelson, daughter of Jenn Nelson, and Pachy Burns at play on shearing day. Jenn Nelson met Piney Hardiman, Pachy's oldest daughter, while they were both in college. Jenn participated in some of the early "Jam to Lamb" events back in the early 1990s. Paws Up Ranch, Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.
Esteban Millan Lozano, Sr. (left corner) and Pachy Burns packing wool in large sacks. Rufo Lozano at top. Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.
Near the day's end . . . after several hundred sheep had been sheared. I counted 18 bundles at the time, with more to come. Paws Up Ranch property, near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.

Sheep shearing crew, on the property of Paws Up Ranch, Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005. From left to right: Dan Ward, Elliston, Montanan--Will Tusick, Polson, Montana--Cyndee and Keith Braeten, Stanford, Montana--Jason Braeten, Kalispell, Montana--Michael H. Peters, Belfry, Montana.

Running sheep, photograph made with a plastic Holga Camera (and only advancing the film part way to reach exposure). Neary Greenough, Montana--across the road and up a few miles from where "Jam to Lamb" was held the previous spring (2004). Spring, 2005.
Running lambs, photograph made with a plastic Holga Camera. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.

Esteban Millan Lozano, Sr., pouring coffee for me in his small camper trailer, a few miles south of the base camp for Pachy Burns' operation. Near Greenough, Montana. He invited us to come to Peru, where he is from and lives for a few months out of the year. I began to make plans, but it never happened . . . which I truly regret.
Esteban Millan Lozano, Sr. walking with his dogs and herding sheep. A few hundred yards from his camper, and a few miles south of the base camp. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.
The camper where Esteban Millan Lozano, Sr. stayed during the night. A few miles south of the base camp, near Greenough, Montana. Spring, 2005.

Esteban Millan Lozano, Sr. baking potatoes in his camper oven--The next image was made at the base camp the following morning; of his sons, Esteban, Jr. and Rufo. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two negatives printed consecutively (one in the evening, the next in the morning).

did.unittitle: Rufo Lozano, the youngest son of Esteban Millan Lozano, Sr. walking with dead lamb. A few miles from Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.
Recently sheared sheep near the base camp constructed by the Lozano brothers and their father. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.

Rufo Lozano, youngest son of Esteban Millan Lozano, Sr., feeding "bum" lambs (rejected for unknown reasons by their birth mothers). Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005. His back is resting on a very old log structure that happened to be on the property leased to Pachy Burns.
Pachy Burns taking off her own jacket and offering it to Ricky Lozano, who had just arrived from Peru. A few miles north of Greenough, Montana. Spring, 2005.
Esteban Jr., his father (right) and brother (left) sorting sheep shortly after shearing. Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.

A day or two after the sheep had been sheared. From left to right: Esteban, Jr., Rufo, Ricky and Esteban Millan Lozano, Sr. on the property of "Paws Up" Ranch (where the sheep shearing took place). Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.

Esteban Millan Lozano, Sr. walking sheep that had been recently sheared. "Paws Up" Ranch (leased to Pachy Burns), Greenough, Montana. Esteban Jr., Sr. and others from Peru were introduced to Pachy by way of an agricultural service in Wyoming.

Lining up sheep in a long chute soon after they have been sheared and administering medicine for de-worming. On the property of Paws Up Ranch, Greenough, Montana. Spring, 2005. (The tube was slipped into their mouths, then injected.)

Esteban Millan Lozano, Jr., tending to a sick ewe and her dead (or dying) lamb. Early morning fog above the base camp--this was the morning of my last day of my visit in the Spring of 2005. A few miles north of Greenough, Montana. (Rufo Lozano is pushing the hay cart in the distance.)
Esteban Millan Lozano, Sr., with his all-terrain vehicle and sheep dogs--just arriving at the base camp, near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.

From left to right: Esteban Millan Lozano, Sr., Esteban, Jr., Ricky and Rufo (father and three sons). These men come from Peru and spend several months out of each year to help Pachy Burns raise and tend sheep. Senior and Junior typically spend the most time in Montana. Pachy met them through an agricultural office in Wyoming. Pachy developed a great deal of respect for their expertise, patience and commitment. Base camp, near Greenough, Montana. Spring, 2005.

Esteban, Jr. keeping watch on sheep. This year's camp was set up across the road from "Paws Up" Ranch in Greenough, Montana. Pens were built in and around the tent in the background. The log structure was more than a hundred years old, but not used specifically for lambing, etc. Spring, 2005.

Esteban, Jr, and his younger brother, Rufo, examining a sick sheep. A couple hundred yards from the base camp, and a few miles north of Greenough, Montana. The buildings and camper beyond them line up near the road that leads to Greenough. Spring, 2005.
Esteban, Jr. and Ricky dragging a sick sheep back to the base camp a couple hundred yards away. Near Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.
Esteban Millan Lozano, Jr., near the base camp for lambing--a few miles from Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005.

Bluesette Campbell, and her older sister, Piney Hardiman--daughters of Pachy Burns--out on the property of their father Daniel "Papa D" Larsen. This area is called Scotch Coulee, and has scattered remnants of what was once a vital mining town. They found a broken cup. October, 2013--the other side of the mountain, from Deer Lodge to their father's is about 8-10 miles.

Bluesette Campbell and Piney Hardiman, daughters of Pachy Burns, having a laugh at an old broken cup they found on their father's property, not far from Red Lodge, Montana. We were visiting their father in October, 2013 (Daniel Lyle Larsen). I found this photograph, and the one which precedes it, to be a nice companion to the tape recorded interviews made during the preceding days with Piney, Bluesette, Jenn Nelson and Dan Larsen. Over the mountain from Red Lodge, Montana--an area called Scotch Coulee.

Daniel Lyle Larsen, father to Piney Hardiman and Bluesette Campbell, and first husband of Judith Faye "Pachy" Burns. "Papa D" a the girls call him, is standing next to his rocket launching apparatus. The following year he will get a permit ot send one of his rockets 6-8 thousand feet into the atmosphere. He is 1/4 Potowatomi Indian. Dan's cabin, just over the hill from Red Lodge, Montana in an area called Scotch Coulee. October, 2013.

Daniel L. Larsen, "Papa D," and his daughter Piney Hardiman near the end of an afternoon visit in October, 2013. Piney, Bluesette and I went up to his cabin/property just over the hill from Red Lodge, Montana. This area where Dan lives is called Scotch Coulee and is an old mining historical site. Bluesette is in the distance . . . we had been searching the ground for old relics, rusted items, kitchen utensils, etc. left behind by mining families.

Piney and Jenn's home, Red Lodge, Montana. Piney Hardiman, Jenn Nelson (originally from Searsport, Maine) and Bluesette Campbell (who lives with her husband and two children in Meadow Lake, Saskatchewan, Canada, where they raise cattle). Red Lodge, Montana--October, 2013.
Bluesette Campbell on her father's property during our visit in October, 2013. Near Red Lodge, Montana (Scotch Coulee).

Judith Faye "Pachy" Burns looking into the mobile sheep shearing unit to make sure her sheep were doing okay while being sheared. Greenough, Montana--Spring, 2005 (late April). Made with a plastic Holga Camera.
Other Images, 2006-2007

did.unittitle: Looking west, under the Mississippi River Bridge, Memphis, Tennessee. After a rare snowstorm. Holga plastic "panoramic" camera, 2006 February (6x20 inch print)
The godhead statue from behind (god the father, son, holy ghost). Salt Lake City, Utah, August 2007

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual recordings are closed to use. Listening copies are available.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of a publication on Asian migrant communities in N.C. containing Chatterley's work on Cambodian Americans, and five audio cassette tapes with interviews of Chatterley discussing his career as a documentary photographer. The interviews have been digitized and stored on a library server; listening copies must be made for access. Please consult with a reference archivist before coming to use this material.

did.unittitle: Barbara Lau, From Cambodia to Greensboro: Tracing the Journeys of New North Carolinians. [Exhibit catalogue] With contributions by Thomas A. Tweed and Sally Peterson, and photographs by Cedric N. Chatterley, Greensboro Historical Museum, 2004

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Greensboro Historical Museum mounted an exhibition from December 2003 to December 2005 entitled From Cambodia to Greensboro: Tracing the Journeys of New North Carolinians. 2003 marked the twentieth anniversary of the Cambodian community in Greensboro, North Carolina, and the exhibition and book traced the community's growth and the experiences of its population.
